occurrence_remarks: The non-indigenous ascidian Distaplia bermudensis from the western Atlantic Ocean was found for the first time in the year 2000 in the Taranto Seas (Ionian Sea, southern Italy) where an abundant population of beautiful colonies is present. In the Taranto Seas D. bermudensis occurs on natural and artifcial hard substrata at depths of 0.5 to 3.5 m. This species may have entered the Mediterranean as a fouling organism on ships hulls.

occurrence_remarks: A project funded by TUBITAK (The Scientific and Technological Research Council of Turkey, Project No: 104Y065) has been undertaken in the summer of 2005 to investigate zoobenthic communities, and the alien species therein, along the Turkish Levantine coast. In the course of the project, nine alien species, previously unknown from the Turkish coast, were photographed and identified. [...] Except for Pyura (=Herdmania) momus and Parupeneus forsskali, the species were sampled during a cruise held in September and October 2005. Pyura (=Herdmania) momus was photographed at station K45 on August 28, 2001 and P. forsskali at station K19 in August 13, 2004.

occurrence_remarks: A project funded by TUBITAK (The Scientific and Technological Research Council of Turkey, Project No: 104Y065) has been undertaken in the summer of 2005 to investigate zoobenthic communities, and the alien species therein, along the Turkish Levantine coast. In the course of the project, nine alien species, previously unknown from the Turkish coast, were photographed and identified. [...] Except for Pyura (=Herdmania) momus and Parupeneus forsskali, the species were sampled during a cruise held in September and October 2005. Pyura (=Herdmania) momus was photographed at station K45 on August 28, 2001 and P. forsskali at station K19 in August 13, 2004.

source: Pérès, J.-M. (1958). Ascidies récoltées sur les côtes méditerranéennes d'Israël. The Bulletin of the Research Council of Israel. 7: 143-150.
occurrence_remarks: Herdmania momus, espèce de mer Rouge, nouvelle pour la Méditerranée, est extrêmement commune sur les côtes d'Israël. Elle figure dans la présente collection sous les NOS N.S. 281-282-283-284 (Méditerranée, sans précision de station) et je l'ai reçue en abondance de la Baie de Haïfa. L'espèce est bien acclimatée et on trouve de nombreux exemplaires avec gonades mûres.

occurrence_remarks: The distribution of this species on the coasts of the Middle and Southern Atlantic States requires further investigation. It is widely distributed on the European coasts and is very common in shallow water on the shores of southern New England and Long Island, often growing on eel grass. I have no records between New Jersey and Florida, though I cannot suppose it is absent from that part of the coast, as the National Museum collection contains flourishing colonies from Cedar Keys and off Gasparilla Light (7 fathoms) on the west coast of Florida. I failed to find it in my collecting at Bermuda and in southeastern Florida.

occurrence_remarks: The colonial styelid Polyandrocarpa zorritensis (Van Name, 1931) has been found in the harbour of La Spezia (North Tirreno). [...] The species was first found in the shallow water of the inner section of the Roads of La Spezia during the summer of 1974. Some colonies were periodically observed in the field, and pieces of them collected in 1975 and 1976. [...] The species described here has so fat not been included among Mediterranean ascidians (Peres, 1958).

source: Bishop, M. W. H. (1947). Establishment of an Immigrant Barnacle in British Coastal Waters. Nature. 159(4041): 501-502.
occurrence_remarks: [...] record the establishment in British waters of an austral barnacle, which appears to have arrived as a component of ship-fouling. [...] The examination of small, unpainted 'Bakelite' panels immersed for successive monthly periods at constant depths of 2 ft. and 4 ft. from the Admiralty Raft inside the mouth of Chichester Harbour, West Sussex, has shown that heavy settlements of acorn barnacles characterize the fouling settling at this site from mid-March to the end of October. These barnacles have been identified as Elminius modestus Darwin, a common estuaring barnacle in southern Australia and New Zealand, and Balanus improvisus Darwin, a commong estuarine form in British and northern temperate waters. [...] In July 1945 the average numbers were two hundred E. modestus and two B. improvisus per square inch of surface area. occurrence_remarks: Reported by Bishop (1951) in Western Australia, but there are no further Australian records (Furlani 1996). Bishop (1951) suggested B. improvisus had become established in one of the southern Australian ports during the 1940s. However, from fouling studies of submerged surfaces on the eastern Australian coast, Allen (1953) could not substantiate this claim. There are no subsequent records of this species occurring in Australian waters in either Australian Museums records or in the published literature (pers. comm. Di Jones 2003).

locality: Dutch part of the North Sea
source: Holthuis, L.B.; Heerebout, G.R. (1972). Vondsten van de zeepok Balanus tintinnabulum (Linnaeus, 1758) in Nederland. Zoologische Bijdragen. 13: 24-31.
occurrence_remarks: Balanus tintinnabulum (L.) , although not indigenous in the Netherlands, has been found at several occasions washed ashore on the Dutch coast. Most specimens evidently originate from fouling growth of ship's hulls. The earliest known record was recently discovered in an unpublished manuscript, wherein live specimens were described and figured, obtained from a ship coming from West Africa and wrecked on the Dutch shore on 8 November 1764. On p. 27 a list of all known recent specimens found washed up on the North Sea coast of the Netherlands is given. Fossil specimens are quite frequently found in the Wester Schelde (province of Zeeland).

source: Galil, B.S.; Kress, N.; Shiganova, T.A. (2009). First record of Mnemiopsis leidyi A. Agassiz, 1865 (Ctenophora; Lobata; Mnemiidae) off the Mediterranean coast of Israel. Aquatic Invasions 4(2): 357-360.
occurrence_remarks: The American comb jelly, Mnemiopsis leidyi, was first noted off the central Mediterranean coast of Israel on 3 March 2009, when a swarm interfered with the operation of a desalination plant. Throughout the spring dense populations have been recorded along the entire Israeli coast. The occurrence of M. leidyi in the SE Levant is of great concern because its notorious impacts on fisheries and because its swarms clog seawater intake pipes and hamper the operation of coastal installations.

locality: Italian part of the Ionian Sea
source: Boero, F.; Putti, M.; Trainito, E.; Prontera, E.; Piraino, S.; Shiganova, T. (2009). First records of Mnemiopsis leidyi (Ctenophora) from the Ligurian, Thyrrhenian and Ionian Seas (Western Mediterranean) and first record of Phyllorhiza punctata (Cnidaria) from the Western Mediterranean. Aquatic Invasions. 4(4): 675-680.
occurrence_remarks: The first records of M. leidyi were made offshore, from boats in the Ligurian Sea, in May 2009, but no pictures were provided. Being the first known records of the species in this part of the Western Mediterranean, these observations were considered as dubious due to lack of proper documentation. In June 2009, a swarm of M. leidyi in the Ligurian Eastern Riviera was photographed repeatedly. The organisms were clearly identifiable as M. leidyi. The species was present in that area continuously throughout the summer, until its decline. When the swarms started to dissolve, numerous specimens of the fish Sarpa salpa (L., 1758) were seen to feed upon the spent ctenophores. The complete list of sightings (occasionally backed up by photographs) is reported in Table 1.

occurrence_remarks: During a survey of the benthic fauna in the vicinty of Haifa Port, a site sampled annually for the past five years, a single specimen of Melicertus hathor was collected in 1997. A year later, trawl-fishery samples collected off the southern Israeli coast have brought up additional specimens. Melicertus hathor is recorded for the first time from the Mediterranean.

source: Holthuis, L. B. (1961). Report on a collection of crustacea decapoda and stomatopoda from Turkey and the Balkans. Zoologische Verhandelingen. 47: 1-67, Pls. 1-2.
occurrence_remarks: Material: 5 km off the south-east coast of Turkey near Mersin; 10 m deep; bottom sand; fished with local fishing boat; 18 May 1959; no. 96. 2 females. The specimens are 115 and 170 mm long. This too is an Indo-West Pacific species, which has entered the eastern Mediterranean by way of the Suez Canal. In the Indo-West Pacific area the range of the species extends from India to the Red Sea. The eastern Mediterranean records are from the Bay of Abukir near Alexandria, from Port Said, and from the Israel coast. The species is now for the first time reported from Turkey.

occurrence_remarks: Material examined: Lagoon of Kishon River, north of Haifa, Israel; 25 September 1958; H. Steinitz and A. Ben-Tuvia, NS. 618. - 2 males, 6 juveniles. [...] Metapenaeus stebbingi was originally described from the Red Sea, from where it was later repeatedly reported. The species is also known from the coast of East Africa (Mozambique and Delagoa Bay), and from Madagascar, while Tirmizi (1962) dealt with specimens from Pakistan (Arabian Sea off Karachi). No records of the species from localities farther east are known to us. M. stebbingi is quite common in the Suez Canal [...] and has reached the eastern Mediterranean. So far the only published Mediterranean records of the species are from Port Said and the Bay of Abukir near Alexandria. The present find of the species in Israel waters extends the known Mediterranean range of the species considerably to the north.

source: Mura, M.; Murenu, M.; Cau, A. (2002). The occurrence of Penaeopsis serrata Bate, 1881 (Decapoda, Penaeidae) in the middle-west Mediterranean Sea. Crustaceana. 75(10): 1263-1269.
occurrence_remarks: In this note we report on eleven specimens of a species of the genus Penaeopsis, found for the first time in the middle-west Mediterranean Sea. The specimens are adult females of the pink-speckled shrimp, P. serrata Bate, 1881 caught in July and September 2001 during a sampling programme aimed at studying the composition and structure of the bathyal communities on the continental slope of the Sardinian Channel.

locality: Israeli part of the Mediterranean Sea - Eastern Basin
source: Galil, B. (2006). A rare record of Hyastenus hilgendorfi (Crustacea: Decapoda: Majidae) from the Levant. Aquatic Invasions. 1(4): 284-285.
occurrence_remarks: The majid crab Hyastenus hilgendorfi is one of the rarest Erythrean alien decapod species in the Mediterranean, with just two records off the Israeli coast in 1960 and 1977. On 21 September, 2004 it was collected again from the central Mediterranean coast of Israel. [...] An examination of the decapod holdings of the National Collections, prompted by the recent finding [in 2004], unearthed an unpublished record, collected by the author, off the central Mediterranean coast of Israel, i.e. a single male specimen (CL 13.8 mm, TL 18.8 mm), was collected off Palmahim (31°55'N, 34°40'E), at depth of 18 m, on 23 January 1977, by the author (TAU AR 16282).

locality: Italian part of the Adriatic Sea
source: Mizzan, L. (1993). Presence of swimming crabs of the genus Callinectes (Stimpson) (Decapoda, Portunidae) in the Venice Lagoon (North Adriatic sea - Italy): first record of Callinectes danae Smith in European waters. Boll. Mus. civ. St. nat. Venezia. 42 (1991): 31-43.
occurrence_remarks: In the collections of the Museum [Natural History Museum of Venice], I also found out a male specimen of Portunid, clearly belonging to the genus Callinectes, but sensibly different from C. sapidus, which had been identified in dubitative form as Callinectes prope danae Smith. The specimen [...] had been caught in the VEnice Lagoon by Flavio Crescentini on 06.09.1981. An accurate analysis [...] has made it possible [...] to identify the specimen definitely as Callinectes danae Smith.

source: Mizzan, L. (1993). Presence of swimming crabs of the genus Callinectes (Stimpson) (Decapoda, Portunidae) in the Venice Lagoon (North Adriatic sea - Italy): first record of Callinectes danae Smith in European waters. Boll. Mus. civ. St. nat. Venezia. 42 (1991): 31-43.
occurrence_remarks: In the period 1991-1992 two male specimens of blue crab Callinectes sapidus Rathbun were caught by local fishers in the Venice Lagoon. [...] one collected on 6.10-1991, the other on 13.10.1992 [...] Carefully examining the zoological collections of the Institute (Natural History Museum of Venice), I found out two other specimens of Callinectes sapidus Rathbun identified and labelled as: Neptunus (= Portunus) pelagicus (Linnaeus, 1758), female, inventory n° 7270 Marina di Grado (Gulf of Venice, 04.10.1949; Neptunus (= Portunus) pelagicus (Linnaeus, 1758), male, inventory n° 7268, Lagoon of Venice, 08.10.1950. These two specimens, [...] had been used for the unfortunately inexact record of Neptunus pelagicus (Linnaeus, 1758) in the North Adriatic Sea (A. Giordani Soika, 1951). Therefore, the presence of the species in the Gulf of Venice, though probably discontinuous, is to be traced back at least to these dates.

source: Lewinsohn, C.; Holthuis, L. B. (1964). New records of Decapod Crustacea from the Mediterranean coast of Israel and the Eastern Mediterranean. Zoologische Mededelingen. 40(8): 45-63.
occurrence_remarks: The species was found for the first time in Israel waters in the summer of 1961, when Dr. E. Gilat during an investigation of the Israel coastal waters south of Tel-Aviv collected material at depths of about 20 fathoms. Dr. Gilat's monthly exploration of these waters in the summer and autumn of 1961 proved that Charybdis longicollis occurred there in great numbers near the 20 fathoms line. [...] The species became so abundant in southern Israel coastal waters that it now must be considered a true pest. [...] Farther north along the Israel coast the species is still less abundant. That it does occur there, however, is proved by the find of a dead female specimen on the beach south of Acre (30 April 1962, E. Gilat and L.B. Holthuis).

occurrence_remarks: Berried females of Thalamita gloriensis Crosnier, 1962, were found in Genoa harbour on the keel of a drilling platform brought to the Mediterranean Sea via Suez, and on the coast of Sardinia in a rock pool. A possible spread of this species is predicted because of its resistance in new environments.

source: Holthuis, L. B.; Gottlieb, E. (1958). An annotated list of the decapod Crustacea of the Mediterranean coast of Israel, with an appendix listing the Decapoda of the eastern Mediterranean. Bulletin of the Research Council of Israel, Section B. Zoology. 7, 1-126.
occurrence_remarks: We examined four males (cl. 4 to 14 mm) and one female (cl. 9 mm) [of Thalamita poissonii] from the shore of Haifa Bay between Kishon and Naaman rivers (17.11.1956) and one male (cl. 16 mm) from Bat Yam (10.VIII.1952, coll. Tel Aviv Institute of Natural Science). [Thalamita poissonii is an Indo-West Pacific species, which is known from the Red Sea, the Iranian Gulf, the W Indian Ocean (Laccadive Islands, Chagos Archipelago, Saya de Malha, Ceylon) and Formosa. It is now reported for the first time from the Mediterranean, having evidently arrived there by way of the Suez Canal, whence it was reported by Caiman (1927).

locality: Turkish part of the Mediterranean Sea - Eastern Basin
source: Holthuis, L. B. (1961). Report on a collection of crustacea decapoda and stomatopoda from Turkey and the Balkans. Zoologische Verhandelingen. 47: 1-67, Pls. 1-2.
occurrence_remarks: Material: South coast of Turkey near Selimiye, about 62 km E. by S. from Antalya; 0-1 m deep; under stones near old roman harbour; 23 April 1959; no. 60. 2 males. South coast of Turkey near Selimiye; 0-1 m deep; sandy bottom with stones and Posidonia vegetation; 4 May 1959; no. 71. 1 male. [...] Thalamita poissonii is a species which originally inhabited the Indo-West Pacific region (Red Sea, Iranian Gulf, western Indian Ocean, Formosa), but which has penetrated into the eastern Mediterranean by way of the Suez Canal. The only previous record of the species from the Mediterranean is the one by Holthuis & Gottlieb (1958) who reported upon material from Israel.

source: Streftaris, N.; Zenetos, A.; Papathanassiou, E. (2005). Globalisation in marine ecosystems: the story of non-indigenous marine species across European seas. Oceanogr. Mar. Biol. Ann. Rev. 43: 419-453.

locality: Egyptian part of the Mediterranean Sea - Eastern Basin
source: Ramadan, S. E.; Dowidar, N. M. (1976). Brachyura (Decapoda Crustacea) from the Mediterranean waters of Egypt. Thalassia Jugoslavica. 8: 127-139.
occurrence_remarks: Spaerozius nitidus is an Indo-Pacific form found in Madagascar, Borneo, Siam, China, Japan, Hawaii and the Red Sea. It was recorded from the Port Said Harbour and the northern part of the Suez Canal in April 1969 (2 males), September 1969 (one female), and March 1970 (one female) and January 1971 (one female). It seems that this species has recently invaded the Mediterranean through the Suez Canal. It was not recorded from the Eastern Mediterranean or even the Suez Canal prior to this record. Furthermore its occurrence in the Mediterranean is, as yet, probably confined to the area of Port Said.

occurrence_remarks: The first find of this species was that of an empty carapace near Tel-Aviv (NS. 575) in April 1961. The first living specimen was encountered shortly afterwards during the summer of 1961 near Mikhmoreth (NS. 860). [...] Until now the species was known only from the Indo-West Pacific area (Red Sea and Natal to the Malay Archipelago and Fiji). It evidently entered the eastern Mediterranean by way of the Suez Canal; it has not been reported before from either the Mediterranean or the Suez Canal.

locality: Egyptian part of the Mediterranean Sea - Eastern Basin
source: Lewinsohn, C. & L.B. Holthuis, 1978. On a new species of Alpheus (Crustacea Decapoda, Natantia) from the eastern Mediterranean. Zoologische Mededelingen 53: 75-82.
occurrence_remarks: From 30 October to 3 November 1975 an expedition, organized by the Department of Zoology of the University of Tel-Aviv, investigated the marine fauna of the Eastern Mediterranean north of Sinai Peninsula. [...] In the collections a species of Alpheus was found which proved to be different from any species so far reported from the Mediterranean. Therefore it was suspected that it was of Indo-West Pacific origin and had migrated from the Red Sea through the Suez Canal. Although a closer examination of the material showed that it indeed is closely related to several Indo-West Pacific species, it could not be assigned to any of the known species. Therefore it is described here as new [Alpheus migrans].

occurrence_remarks: Material and methods: During the 1988-1991 cruises of R.V. Bilim and R.V. Çubuklu in the gulf of Iskenderun, sediment samples were taken from 5 cm of the top layer using a Dietz Lafonde grab sampler and all sample material stored originally at room temperature was available dry in sealed plastic bags. [] Some species have been recorded for the first time in the Turkish coasts. Indeed, these species are extremely rare, infrequent and generally restricted to extremely limited locations, except Septloculina spp. The relative abundance of these species are less than 1% in total benthic foraminiferal fauna of the Gulf of Iskenderun including Articulina mayori, Dentalina subsoluta, Spiroloculina ornata tricarinata, Fursenkoina schreibersiana, Nodosaria subpervesa, Sigmohauerina bradyi, Planisipirinella exigua, Nubeculoculina divaricata, Siphonina pulchra, Triloculina asymetrica, Planorbulina acervalis, Trifarina bradyi, Pseudomassilina austrailis and as mentioned earlier, Septloculina angul

source: Murphy, D.F.; Holmes, J.M.C. (1990). Heterolaophonte hamondi Hicks (Crustacea: Copepoda): Harpacticoida) new to Ireland. Irish Naturalists' Journal. 23(5-6): 225.
occurrence_remarks: One of us (DFM) maintains a small marine aquarium. Seawater for the aquarium was obtained from the Blackrock area of Dublin Bay. Approximately 100 liters were collected every six months, at high tide level on the shore at either of two places: near Blackrock station (O215295), or alternatively near Seapoint (O227288). The gravle for the bottom of the aquarium, anc various examples of marine life, were also collected at the Seapoint site. On March 1986 a female harpacticoid copepod was collected from the lower layers of gravel at the bottom of the aquarium. It was identified by JMCH as Heterolaophonte hamondi Hicks, a species not hitherto found in Ireland. Further specimens, all female, were found in similar circumstances in the aquarium in April and May 1986, July 1987 and January 1988. The precise locality for these specimens is problematical, but they must have come originally from either Blackrock or Seapoint, 1.7 km apart on the S shore of Dublin Bay.

occurrence_remarks: A project funded by TUBITAK (The Scientific and Technological Research Council of Turkey, Project No: 104Y065) has been undertaken in the summer of 2005 to investigate zoobenthic communities, and the alien species therein, along the Turkish Levantine coast. In the course of the project, nine alien species, previously unknown from the Turkish coast, were photographed and identified. [...] Except for Pyura (=Herdmania) momus and Parupeneus forsskali, the species were sampled during a cruise held in September and October 2005. Pyura (=Herdmania) momus was photographed at station K45 on August 28, 2001 and P. forsskali at station K19 in August 13, 2004.

locality: Dutch part of the North Sea
source: Saraber, J.G.A.M. (1962). Ostroumovia inkermanica in the Netherlands. Beaufortia. 9(100): 117-120.
occurrence_remarks: During an examination of the Hydromedusae from the Netherlands and adjacent waters present in the collections of the Rijksmuseum van Natuurlijke Historie at Leiden, the Zoological Museum at Amsterdam, and the Zoological Station at Den Helder, some specimens of a medusa were found that proved to belong to <i>Ostroumovia inkermanica (Partschikowa-Ostroumowa, 1925), a species not previously reported from the region. As the collection, mentioned above, did not contain specimens identified with this name, some of the medusae were sent to Dr. P.L. Kramp, Zoological Museum, Copenhagen, who kindly examined them and confirmed the identification. The specimens were collected on September 23, 1959, in the Grote Sluis (large lock) of the North Sea Canal at IJmuiden, in surface plankton, salinity 7.00 promille, by Dr. J.H. Stock of the Zoological Museum at Amsterdam, and are preserved in formaline 4%.

locality: Swedish part of the Baltic Sea
source: Brodin, Y.; Andersson, M.H. (2008). The marine splash midge Telmatogeton japonicus (Diptera; Chironomidae) - extreme and alien?. Biological Invasions. 11: 1311-1317.
occurrence_remarks: We found all developmental stages of the midge Telmatogeton japonicus (Chironomidae) on offshore windmills near the major Swedish seaport Kalmar in the southern Baltic Sea. This might be the first record of an insect species really inhabiting the offshore areas of the Baltic Sea. [...] surveying the fish community around the seven offshore windmills at the wind farm Utgrunden 1 in the southern Kalmar Strait of the Baltic Sea, observations were made by M. H. Andersson in August 2007 of a frequent occurrence of a dark midge on the windmill foundations in the splash zone. When returning in October the same year, three samples of the adult midge were recovered by a SCUBA diver swimming in the surface water using a small landing net. [...] The population of T. japonicus at Utgrunden 1 is the northernmost one so far reported from the Baltic Sea. Previous findings are from the northern coast of Poland in the 1970s (Szadziewski 1977) and Germany in the 1960s and 1980s (Remmert 19

[...] Except for Pyura (=Herdmania) momus and Parupeneus forsskali, the species were sampled during a cruise held in September and October 2005. occurrence_remarks: One specimen of daggertooth pike-conger, Muraenesox cinereus (Forsskal, 1775), 1199 mm TL, was caught on 27.IX.1979 by hook-and-line in the vicinity of Tel Aviv-Jaffa, Mediterranean coast of Israel. Muraenesox cinereus has not hitherto been reported from either the Suez Canal or the Gulf of Suez but one speciment was found recently in the Gulf of Elat (Gulf of 'Aqaba). This specimen (HUJ-F 10606), 901 mm TL, was caught in VII.1981 by hook-and-line off Nuweiba at a depth of ca. 300 m.

occurrence_remarks: Three fish species, Bregmaceros atlanticus Goode et Bean, 1886 (Bregmacerotidae), Echiodon dentatus (Cuvier, 1829) (Carapidae), and Nemichthys scolopaceus Richardson, 1848 (Nemichthyidae) were recorded in the Sigacik and Kusadasi Bays (Eastern Aegean Sea, Turkey). occurrence_remarks: Flying fish from the eastern part of the Mediterranean are very little known, and most identifications have not been controlled by comparison with material from the Atlantic. Dr. E. Liebman, of Jerusalem, has recently sent me two specimens from the Palestine coast, both of which are adults (standard lengths 95-103 mm.) of the primitive genus Parexocoetus, Bleeker. Parexocoetus has not been recorded from the Mediterranean before. They belong to the specie P. mento, C. and V.

source: Kovacic, M.; Golani, D. (2007). First record of Papillogobius melanobranchus in the Mediterranean Sea and new data on geographic distributions, bathymetric ranges and morphology of several small benthic fishes in the Levant. Cybium. 31(4): 417-425.
occurrence_remarks:
Material examined. - 1 male, 33.7 + 8.8 mm, HUJ 13452, Bardawil Lagoon, Northern Sinai, Egypt, 12 Apr. 1969 [...] C. ochetica was described by Norman (1927) as assigned to the genus of Gobius from seven specimens from Port Said, Egypt. It was considered to be a Lessepsian migrant since its distribution included only the Red Sea and the Isthmus of Suez (Golani et al., 2006). It inhabits shallow water, isolated hard substrate but found occasionally on sandy substrate (Goren, 1985). The present record, from the Bardawil Lagoon constitutes the first Mediterranean record of this species out of the Suez Isthmus.

Change in establishment success from 'casual' to 'established' based on: Zenetos, A.; Meric, E.; Verlaque, M.; Galli, P.; Boudouresque, C.; Giangrande, A.; Cinar, M.; Bilecenoglu, M. (2008). occurrence_remarks: Upeneus moluccensis (Bleeker) is now common enough in the eastern Mediterranean to be of economic importance and has been mentioned several times under a wrong identification as Mulloidichtys auriflamma (Forskal). A careful examination of an extensive material from the Israeli coast and from Mersin, Turkey, revealed that all the fish belong to a single species, U. moluccensis.

Berg, M. (1977). Pink salmon, Onchorhynchus gorbuscha (Walbaum) in Norway. Inst. Freshw. Res. Drottningholm. 56: 12-17.
occurrence_remarks: During the years 1933-39, Sovjet fishery biologists tried unsuccessfully to transplant chum salmon (Oncorhynchus keta, Walbaum) into the Atlantic. In 1956, these attempts were resumed, this time with both pink and chum salmon (Berg 1961). Pink salmon have been caught in varying numbers from year to year since 1960. The first time a few pink salmon were caught in Norwegian waters may have been in 1958 (Abrahamsen, pers. comm.). The fishermen did not then know the fish and did not send them in for examination, so the information cannot be confirmed. [...] Norwegian record in 1960: 20-25,000 kg. Reports from more than 40 rivers in North Norway and found over the whole country. A number of spawning pink observed in many rivers in North Norway.

occurrence_remarks: This species occurs abundantly in the Levantine Sea between 0.1 and 75 m depths (preferably in shallow-water benthic habitats) (Çinar, 2009), but has not been reported from the Aegean Sea so far. The present paper shows that C. mirabilis is extending its distributional range to the northern part of the Mediterranean. The species was considered as a Lessepsian migrant and previously reported from the Red Sea, western Atlantic, Indian Ocean, Pacific Ocean and Mediterranean (Day, 1967).

occurrence_remarks: Dix-neuf stations différentes ont été prospectées à une ou plusieurs reprises entre le 15 avril 1974 et la mai 1975. source: Çinar, M. (2006). New records of alien species on the Levantine coast of Turkey. Aquatic Invasions. 1(2): 84-90.
occurrence_remarks: A project funded by TUBITAK (The Scientific and Technological Research Council of Turkey, Project No: 104Y065) has been undertaken in the summer of 2005 to investigate zoobenthic communities, and the alien species therein, along the Turkish Levantine coast. In the course of the project, nine alien species, previously unknown from the Turkish coast, were photographed and identified. [...] Except for Pyura (=Herdmania) momus and Parupeneus forsskali, the species were sampled during a cruise held in September and October 2005. Pyura (=Herdmania) momus was photographed at station K45 on August 28, 2001 and P. forsskali at station K19 in August 13, 2004.

locality: Italian part of the Tyrrhenian Sea
source: Lardicci, C.; Castelli, A. (1986). Desdemona ornata Banse, 1957, (Polychaeta, Sabellidae, Fabricinae) new record in the Mediterranean Sea. Oebalia. 13: 195-200.
occurrence_remarks: The finding of Desdemona ornata Banse (Sabellidae, Fabricinae) in a brackish «microhabitat» of Elba Island (Tuscan Archipelago) is reported. This is a new species for the Mediterranean Sea, to date known only in some brackish basins of the southern hemisphere. Moreover, it is one of the first findings of the genus Desdemona in the northern hemisphere. [...] Nine specimens were examined. They came from the «Fosso della Madonnina», a small seasonal stream which opens into the Bay of Portoferraio, located along the northern coasts of Elba Island (Tuscan Archipelago), with a salinity ranged between 25-30 %.

locality: Greek part of the Aegean Sea
source: Panagopoulos, D.; Nicolaidou, A. (1990). A population of Desdemona ornata Banse, (Polychaeta, Sabellidae) settled in a fully marine habitat of the Mediterannean. Oebalia. 16: 35-39.
occurrence_remarks: The paper reports the settlement of a population of Desdemona ornata Banse in a fully marine and polluted environment in Elefsis Bay, Saronikos Gulf, Greece. D. ornata may be an opportunistic species, taking advantage of unpredictable estuarine or polluted environments, which in this case was carried into the area by ships. [...] A preliminary survey was carried out in May, 1986. D. ornata was found in 6 out of the 10 stations sampled and its numbers ranged from 1 to 67 individuals per sample. Further sampling between January 1987 and May 1987 also yielded a number of D. ornata.[...] Very few records of D. ornata exist in the literature. This is the first time the species is recorded in Greece. The occurrence of D. ornata in Elefsis Bay is neither temporary nor accidental. The population, which was found in May 1986, continued to exist a year later, although changes in its density did take place.

occurrence_remarks: H. elegans was discovered only on the artificial surfaces in Golden Horn Inlet (port Vladivostok), where this species may occur because of thermal pollution due to the discharge of warm waters of the water cooling system of Thermal-Electric Power Station-2 (TEPS-2) in Vladivostok which has been in function since 1971. The abundant population of H. elegans exists in the bay throughout the year and is capable of reproduction. The biomass of H. elegans may reach several kg/m2 in August-September.

occurrence_remarks: Polydora colonia Moore, 1907 (Polychaeta, Spionidae) is cited and described for the first time from the Mediterranean and the Iberan Peninsula. [...] Se han estudiado siete ejemplares, capturados en la Playa Torrecilla en Nerja (Málaga) procedentes de concreciones calcáreas del alga Mesophyllum lichenoides. Las muestras fueron recogidas mediante buceo con escafandra autónoma y a profundidades de entre 3 y 4 m. En cade muestra se tomoó una concreción completa de , al menos, 20 cm de diámetro y de aproximadamente 10 cm de altura. Fechas de captura: 1 ejemplar 11-II-1983, 3 ejemplares 29-IV-1983 y 3 ejemplares 14-VI-1983.

source: Dagli, E.; C¸inar, M. E. (2008). Invasion of polluted soft substratum of Izmir Bay (Aegean Sea, eastern Mediterranean) by the spionid polychaete worm, Pseudopolydora paucibranchiata (Polychaeta: Spionidae). Cahiers de Biologie Marine. 49(1): 87-96.
occurrence_remarks: The present study reports the first occurrence of an alien spionid polychete worm, Pseudopolydora paucibranchiata Okuda 1937, in the Mediterranean Sea. This species, which was previously identified as P. antennata Claparède, 1870, formed a dense population in and near Alsancak Harbor (Izmir Bay, Aegean Sea), especially in June 2004. It was also found at some stations in Iskenderun and Mersin Bays in September 2005 (Levantine Sea). [...] Material: Specimens of Pseudopolydora paucibranchiata were collected at 7 stations in the inner part of Izmir Bay (Aegean Sea) between January and September 2004, and 4 stations in Iskenderun Bay and 1 station in Mersin Bay (Levantine Sea) in September 2005.

locality: Turkish part of the Mediterranean Sea - Eastern Basin
source: Dagli, E.; C¸inar, M. E. (2008). Invasion of polluted soft substratum of Izmir Bay (Aegean Sea, eastern Mediterranean) by the spionid polychaete worm, Pseudopolydora paucibranchiata (Polychaeta: Spionidae). Cahiers de Biologie Marine. 49(1): 87-96.
occurrence_remarks: The present study reports the first occurrence of an alien spionid polychete worm, Pseudopolydora paucibranchiata Okuda 1937, in the Mediterranean Sea. This species, which was previously identified as P. antennata Claparède, 1870, formed a dense population in and near Alsancak Harbor (Izmir Bay, Aegean Sea), especially in June 2004. It was also found at some stations in Iskenderun and Mersin Bays in September 2005 (Levantine Sea). [...] Material: Specimens of Pseudopolydora paucibranchiata were collected at 7 stations in the inner part of Izmir Bay (Aegean Sea) between January and September 2004, and 4 stations in Iskenderun Bay and 1 station in Mersin Bay (Levantine Sea) in September 2005.

occurrence_remarks: This is the first report on Pycnogonida from Israel's Mediterranean coast. The five species listed are: Ammothella longioculata Faraggiana, Achelia echinata Hodge, Tanystylum orbiculare Wilson, Anoplodactylus saxatilis Calman, and A. portus Calman. While the first three species are new to the Eastern Mediterrnanea, Anoplodactylus saxatilis was known only from the Indian Ocean and the Suez Canal. A. portus is a circumtropical species not yet recorded from the Mediterranean Sea. [...] Material collected for Achelia echinata: 1 female. Tantura, Israel. July 1953. Ch. Lewinsohn coll.

source: Krapp, F.; Sconfietti, R. (1983). Ammothea hilgendorfi (Bohm, 1879), an adventitious pycnogonid new for the Mediterranean Sea. Marine Ecology. 4(2): 123-132.
occurrence_remarks: The authors demonstrate the probable immigration and stable settling of the pycnogonid Ammothea hilgendorfi (Böhm, 1879) at one station in the lagoon of Venice. The species is widely distributed naturally on both sides of the Pacific Ocean and has probably immigrated on ship hulls through the Suez Canal to the Mediterranean. [...] Fouling panels measuring 200 x 300 mm were immersed in the tidal zone at Punta Salute, near one of the three entrances of the lagoon of Venice. The panels were regularly retrieved and inspected as part of a series of studies conducted in 1979-1981.

(2) Northern Tunisia, Rass El Assoued (= Cap Négro), 1-2m, between Bizerte (= Banzart) and Tabarka, 22/07/2006-29/07/2006 (SS, OL, 13 colonies recorded). (3) Northern Tunisia, Galite Island, 4m, 6/05/2008 (JGH, 1 colony recorded).

occurrence_remarks: A project funded by TUBITAK (The Scientific and Technological Research Council of Turkey, Project No: 104Y065) has been undertaken in the summer of 2005 to investigate zoobenthic communities, and the alien species therein, along the Turkish Levantine coast. In the course of the project, nine alien species, previously unknown from the Turkish coast, were photographed and identified. [...] Except for Pyura (=Herdmania) momus and Parupeneus forsskali, the species were sampled during a cruise held in September and October 2005. Pyura (=Herdmania) momus was photographed at station K45 on August 28, 2001 and P. forsskali at station K19 in August 13, 2004.

occurrence_remarks: A project funded by TUBITAK (The Scientific and Technological Research Council of Turkey, Project No: 104Y065) has been undertaken in the summer of 2005 to investigate zoobenthic communities, and the alien species therein, along the Turkish Levantine coast. In the course of the project, nine alien species, previously unknown from the Turkish coast, were photographed and identified. [...] Except for Pyura (=Herdmania) momus and Parupeneus forsskali, the species were sampled during a cruise held in September and October 2005. Pyura (=Herdmania) momus was photographed at station K45 on August 28, 2001 and P. forsskali at station K19 in August 13, 2004.

occurrence_remarks: The first record of the non-indigenous Fusinus rostratus in northern Brittany (north-west France) is reported. Seven specimens of this predatory gastropod were found on a muddy maerl matrix at about 10 m depth in the inner part of the bay of Morlaix. This is the first record for the Atlantic coast of France as the species originates from the warmer waters of the Mediterranean, Portugal and northern Spain, and was previously unrecorded in the English Channel.

source: Barash, A.; Danin, Z. (1988/89). Marine Mollusca at Rhodes. Israel Journal of Zoology. 35: 1-74.
occurrence_remarks: Record new to Rhodes: Bogi, personnal communication. Material: Rhodes Is. locality not indicated, VII-1979, 4 m depth, 1 shell (Bogi, personal communication). [...] An expedition to Rhodes was organized by the Hebrew University-Smithsonian Institution Joint Program (1967,1972), in connection with the problems of Lessepsian migration, with the main objective of clarifying whether the Indo-Pacific species which immigrated through the Suez Canal into the Levant Sea had reached also the Dodecanese. The expedition was preliminary and lasted only from 12 to 16 October 1970. Most of the mollusk material was collected at four stations (Kallithea, Katsouni, Khoklakos and Kamiros) (Fig. 1 and Table I) in relatively shallow water near the shore, or on the beaches as drift material; rocky shores with plentiful algal vegetation yielded most species and specimens. The only offshore profile was made in Zephyros Bay where few mollusks were collected by dredging from depths of 10- 65 m.

The sampling was carried out in September 2005.

occurrence_remarks: The Lessepsian migrant Smaragdia souverbiana is here reported for the first time from the Mediterranean coast of Israel. A single shell was found in the intestines of Callionymus filamentosus, a Lessepsian migrant fish species, which had been caught in Haifa Bay in 1987. This record predates the oldest published record of it from Turkey by five years.

occurrence_remarks: Crassostrea gigas (Thunberg, 1793) has been repeatedly introduced for aquaculture since at least 1932, first in the Ghar el Melh lagoon, formerly known as Porto Farina (DANTAN & HELDT, 1932, as Crassostrea angulata) and later in the Bizerte lagoon and nearby Lake Ichkeul (AZOUZ, 1966; MEDHIOUB & ZAOUALI, 1988; DRIDI et al., 2006). Populations were generally not self-sustained and successful reproduction was only reported in 2002-2003 for the Biz-erte Lagoon (DRIDI et al., 2006).

source: Çevik, C.; Öztürk, B.; Buzzuro, G. (2001). The presence of Crassostrea virginica (Gmelin, 1791) and Saccostrea commercialis (Iredale & Roughley, 1933) in the Eastern Mediterranean Sea. La Conchiglia. 298: 25-28.
occurrence_remarks: In order to determine the molluscan fauna of the eastern Mediterranean coast of Turkey, benthic research was conducted during 1998-1999 at depths ranging to 30 m. It was determined that Crassostrea virginica (Gmelin, 1791), Crassostrea gigas (Thunberg, 1793), and Saccostrea commercialis (Iredale & Roughley, 1933) have established dense populations at some localities. Among these species, C. virginica and S. commercialis are new records for the eastern Mediterranean Sea.

locality: Italian part of the Adriatic Sea
source: Keppel, E.; Sigovini, M.; Tagliapietra, D. (2012). A new geographical record of Polycera hedgpethi Er. Marcus, 1964 (Nudibranchia: Polyceridae) and evidence of its established presence in the Mediterranean Sea, with a review of its geographical distribution. Marine Biology Research. 8(10): 969-981.
occurrence_remarks: This article reports the first record of the Nudibranch Polycera hedgpethi in the Lagoon of Venice (Italy), as well as its established presence in the Mediterranean Sea after its first record in 1986 in lake Fusaro (Naples). In less than 50 years P. hedgpethi has spread throughout the world's temperate and subtropical waters, preferring protected coastal environments and other semi-enclosed coastal water bodies such as ports, harbours and lagoons. Shipping is the most likely vector. The species distribution shows a temperatesubtropical range, at about 745° of latitude both North and South. Polycera hedgpethi was collected during a survey in 2009 and its presence confirmed for the following two years. All individuals collected were found attached to the bryozoan Bugula neritina, to which it is linked trophically, suggesting a determined pattern of distribution. The present finding is the northernmost record for the species.

occurrence_remarks: Through the courtesy of prof. dr. Al. Barash, Tel Aviv University, Israel, we recently obtained some material dredged in Haifa Bay by M. Tom in 1974 at depths ranging from 40 to 70 meters. Apart from a number of other interesting species, few specimens of a Chrysallida species where dound which did not correspond with any of the known European species of the genus as recently figured by one of us (van Aartsen, 1977). Clearly we have to do with a Red Sea immigrant species in luch the same was as this is the case with Chrysallida maiae (Hornung & Mermod, 1924). From the work of these same authors (1925: 27), it became clear that we are dealing with Chrysallida fischeri (Hornung & Mermod).

Extensive research has led us to the following identifications : Syrnola cinctella A. Adams, I860 and Iolaea neofelixoides (Nomura, 1936).

occurrence_remarks: Thriving populations of the Spiny Oyster Spondylus spinosus Schreibers, 1793, and Indo-Pacific bivalve, are reported from off the Mediterranean coast of Israel. [...] the presence of a large Spondylus species [later identified as Spondylus spinosus Schreibers, 1793] was noticed by Adam Kotzer, a local fisherman, as early as 1988.

locality: Turkish part of the Mediterranean Sea - Eastern Basin
source: Engl, W.; Çeviker, D. (1999). New migrant species from southeast Turkey: Psammotreta praerupta (Salisbury, 1934) and Antigona lamellaris Schumacher, 1817. La Conchiglia. 290: 17-20.
occurrence_remarks: Mienis et al. (1993) described Spondylus spinosus Schreibers, 1793 as a new migrant species from Israel. It was first found in 1988 and is now forming stable populations in Israel. Henk Mienis was kind enough to send me two specimens of that species for my collection. Nevertheless, I was surprised when I saw that this species is now forming stable populations in southeastern Turkey also. I admired several specimens of that polymorphic species in the collection of D. ceviker. He had found the species live at Ekinciler Mendiregi (Payas, Iskenderun) at a depth of 2-3 m in 1994. It is worth noting that he also found many upper valves of juveniles in shell grit, which demonstrates the existence of a stable reproducing population. Spondylus spinosus is living sympatrically with Spondylus gaederopus at that location.

Some adult and several juvenile specimens were also collected at Palmahim at 30 m.

source: Heppell, D. (1961). The naturalization in Europe of the quahog, Mercenaria mercenaria (L.). Journal of Conchology. 25: 21-34.
occurrence_remarks: The first recorded finding of M. mercenaria in Britain was at Bootle, the specimen being exhibited by Higgins at a meeting of the Literary and Philosophical Society of Liverpool in 1859. Only the empty shell was found and its origin was thought to be ballast. In 1864, however, the species was found to living in the Humber.

occurrence_remarks: [English abstract] The species diversity of phytoplankton in the littoral zone of the Odessa Bay (1995-2000) was studied. 297 (375) species and intraspecies taxons of microalgae are revealed. The comparison with data from 1965-1987 was shown the increase of phytoplankton species diversity with predominance dinoflagellates (39,2%) and diatoms (36,7%). The anthropogenic eutrophication of water in the Odessa Bay is one of the main factors caused the qualitative changes in the phytoplankton structure.

(1) Ogatsu Bay, Ishinomaki, Miyagi; (2) Nabeta Bay, Shimoda, Shizuoka; (3) Senjoujiki, Minami-Izu, Shizuoka; (4) Toushima, Shirahama, Tanabe Bay, Wakayama; and from the hulls of three ships: (5) Ship Y (6) Ship Z at Kobe Port, Hyogo and (7) Ship A at Mizushima Port, Okayama. Samples of M. coccopoma from (8) Manly, Sydney, Australia and (9) Rio de Janeiro, Brazil were used to compare species identity and genetic population structure. [...] See Table 1 in publication.

source: Okada, Y. K. (1933). Syllidian Miscellany. Journal of the Marine Biological Association of the United Kingdom. 18(02): 641-653.
occurrence_remarks: My second visit to the Plymouth Laboratory was in June 1929. This time I obtained a tiny Syllid abundantly on Laminaria covered by Obelia always in close association with Autolytus edwarsi Saint-Joseph. [...] it may be rather risky to identify the present species with the American [Autolytus cornutus] only by its external resemblance. Nevertheless, the following two reasons would make this identification not improbable: first, the species was not found before during my stay from June, 1927, to April of the next year, in spite of its being so common in the summer of 1929. Secondly, this district of England is the first port of Europe touched by steamers coming from America. It is possible that its appearance in Plymouth Sound was due to its being carried by a steamer from its native country. Of course, it is probably not simply carried by adhering to the bottom of a ship, but the latter would first be covered by some hydroids including Obelia, to which the Syllid attaches itself seconda

occurrence_remarks: Twelve specimens of the western Atlantic shrimp, Farfantepenaeus aztecus (Ives, 1891), were caught between December 2009 and June 2010 by bottom trawl off Serik in Antalya Bay, Turkey. The species has probably been introduced in the eastern Mediterranean with ballast water. This is the first record of F. aztecus, and the second of a western Atlantic shrimp in the Mediterranean Sea.

occurrence_remarks: The presence of any individual of Fistularia petimba Lacepéde, 1803 [...] has not been reported previously for Mediterranean waters. Ours is the first record of an individual from this family to be found at such a high latitude as the southern coast of Iberian Peninsula. On 23 June 1996, a Fistularia petimba specimen was captured 3 km off the coast of La Línea de la Concepción (Cadiz, Spain). The fish was caught at a depth of 50 m by a local fishermand using a gillnet locally known as a rachera.

occurrence_remarks: This study reports the presence of three alien molluscs from Iskenderun Bay (SE Turkey). Amathina tricarinata (Linnaeus, 1767) and Petricola hemprichi Issel, 1869 have prior records from other regions of Mediterranean, but, Cardites akabana (Sturany, 1899) first recorded in this paper. Since all of them are present in the Red Sea or Suez Canal, they can be considered as Lessepsian immigrants. [...] Material examined for Amathina tricarinata (Linnaeus, 1767): Seven specimens were found under the spines of the bivalve Spondylus spinosus Schreibers, 1793 from 25 m depth at Yumurtalik (36o4617 N, 35o4957 E) on 12 January 2000.

occurrence_remarks: On 16 September 2007, while SCUBA diving at Saline Joniche (Reggio Calabria, Italy), 37º55'34"N 15º44'26"E, a couple of H. cyanomarginata showing trailing behaviour were found in daytime at a depth of about 6 m on some calcareous boulders [...] After a few days (on 23 September, with a water temperature of about 218C on the bed), in the same place, about 70 specimens (both adults and juveniles from 6 to 20 mm in length) and several egg-masses (principally on Cystoseira sp.) of translucent colour and whitish capsules of H. cyanomarginata were found. [...] Our record, the first for Ionian and all Italian seas, is the furthest north-west Mediterranean station known for Haminoea cyanomarginata, and considerably extends its present distribution.

locality: Italian part of the Ligurian Sea
source: Cattaneo-Vietti, R. (1986). On the probable presence of Chromodoris quadricolor quadricolor (Mollusca: Nudibranchia) in the Mediterranean Sea. Bollettino Malacologico. 22(5-8): 167-168.
occurrence_remarks: In ApriI 1982, Dr. L. Capelli, a good underwater photographer took two photo of an unusual doridacean at 30 m depth near Capo Mortola (Imperia, Ligurian Sea) in a pIace close to several submarine springs. The specimen, about 20 mm long, can be referred to the species Chromodoris quadricolor quadricolor (RUPPELL & LEUCKART, 1828) described from the Red Sea (Tor, Egypt). This nudibranch is well distributed from the East African coast (MARCUS& MARCUS,1 959) to the Australian area (THOMPSON1, 972), but it was never seen in Mediterranean waters. This species presents some geographical and colour varieties (ENGEL & NIJSSEN-MEYER1, 964; BURN, 1968) and far this reason the trinominal Dame is used. The specimen, photographed along the Ligurian coast, seems to be very close, as to colour pattern, to the description given by ENGEL & VAN EEKEN (1962) for a Gulf of Aqaba specimen. Obviously this presence must be confirmed, but the record emphasizes the specific richness of the Mediterranean Opistho

[] The identification of the somewhat damaged shell of this species found in Israel, offered certain difficulties. Prof. Fischer-Piette (Museum d'Histoire Naturelle de Paris) gave his opinion: "chez Glycymeris arabicus (Adams) il-y-a une certaine analogie avec ce genre de sculpture mais comme votre échantillon est cassé dans la region postéro-ventrale, nous ne savons pas s'il presentait la sub-angulosité que possède arabicus dans cette region". (Communication by letter).

occurrence_remarks: A long time ago, my friend Dogan Ceviker sent me a large Tellina from deeper water off Karatas. It was obviously a non-European species and a possibly new migrant species from the eastern Mediterranean. Following OLIVER (1992), D. Ceviker determined this shell as Psammotreta praerupta (Salisbury, 1934) and I confirmed this. Again, I sent one bivalve to P.G. Oliver (NMW) and he agreed with our determination (in litt., 27 Jan. 1998). Oliver reports this species from muddy sands in shallow water with a size up to 50 mm. Psammotreta praerupta has a distribution from Lake Timsah, Great and Little Lakes, and Suez to Aden, as well as the Indo-Pacific region. D. Ceviker obtained the shells from fishermen who were fishing off Karatas (Adana) in depths of 120-180 m. The shells have a maximum size of 53 x 40 mm and were collected from muddy substrates. Four bivalves are in the collection D. Ceviker, two bivalves in the collection W. Engl and one single valve in the collection F. Carrozza (all col

occurrence_remarks: Two additional finds of a loose valve of the Indo-Pacific Venerid species Circenita callipyga (von Born, 1778) are reported from Mediterranean beaches of Israel. Any proof that the species is actually living in the Easern Mediterranean is still lacking. [...] Barash & Danin (1982: 403-404 & 1992: 301, figs. 341a-b: as Gafrarium callipygum) reported a single valve found on the beach of Tel Aviv. This specimen forms still part of the Natioanl Mollusc Collection of the Tel Aviv University (TAU) and is supplied with the following data: Tel Aviv, on the beach, leg. M. Frost, 19 October 1980 (TAU). So far this has remained the only published record of this species from a Mediterranean locality. In the National Mollusc Collection of the Hebrew University of Jerusalem (HUJ) we could register two additional finds of a single valve; Nahariya, on the beach, leg. P.S. Tsuriel, 2 September 1972 (HUJ 7758) and Bat Yam, on the beach, leg. H.K. Mienis, 17 May 1999 (HUJ 36718). This means

occurrence_remarks: Visiting Dogan Ceviker in Istanbul, he showed me a further new migrant species, which he had determined to be Antigona lamellaris Schumacher, 1817. It is an unmistakable shell whose identification was also confirmed by P.G. Oliver. This species has a wide distribution (Suez, Sudan, Aden, Indo-Pacific) and its habitat is in sands offshore (OLIVER, 1992); the size ranges to 35 mm. D. Ceviker found one bivalve in Burnaz (Iskendemn) at the beach after a storm in 1988; its dimensions are 38 x 33 mm; this species belongs to the Veneridae.

Through the Suez Canal it has entered the eastern Mediterranean, being reported from Egypt and Israel. So far the species was not known from Turkey. In the collection of the Rijksmuseum van Natuurlijke Historie there is a sample from Beyrut, Lebanon (1952, don. R. Zariquiey Alvarez).

occurrence_remarks: Recently I could study a relatively small sample of molluscs collected on the 9th January 1974 near Talul, in shallow waters of the lagoon of Bardawil, Northern Sinai. [...] The sample contained to my surprise however also about thirty specimens of Diala (Diala) semistriata (Philippi), a well known species from the Red Sea. It was already known from the Suez Canal (see for instance the extensive references in Moazzo, 1939: 184), but is has not been mentioned before from the Mediterranean.

occurrence_remarks: Two Red Sea species, the sparid Rhabdosargus haffara and the sphyraenid Sphyraena flavicauda, previously unrecorded in the Mediterranean, have been recently found in the vicinity of Tel-Aviv, coast of Israel. [] On 13 May 1991 the author collected at the fishing port of Jaffa a 325 mm (T.L.) specimen of Sphyraena flavicauda in the catch of a trammel net set overnight in the vicinity of Tel-Aviv. On 3 June 1991 the author collected at the same location, a 254 mm (T.L.) specimen of Rhabdosargus haffara caught by the same method. Both species are very common in the Red Sea but were hitherto unrecorded in the Mediterranean.

occurrence_remarks: The western Indian Ocean seahorse Hippocampus fuscus is recorded for the first time in the Mediterranean. Its presence there is probably due to migration from the Red Sea via the Suez Canal. [] On 19 July 2001 a large specimen (144 mm total length, LT) of a female Hippocampus fuscus Ru¨ ppell, known previously only from the western Indian Ocean and Red Sea, was collected during a SCUBA dive in the port of the Hadera power station, Israel, 40 km north of Tel-Aviv. The specimen was found at a depth of 4 m, 2 m above the substratum, on a rope attached to a supporting pillar of the jetty.

occurrence_remarks: A specimen of Diadema setosum was collected by divers of the Lebanese Army in September 2009, found on a rocky bottom in the coastal waters of the town of Monsef (34º10'59.24''N, 35º37'54.93''E; Figure 1) at a relatively shallow depth (10-20 m). source: Ben Souissi, J.; Golani, D.; Mejri, H.; Ben Salem, M.; Capapé, C. (2007). First confirmed record of the Halave's Guitarfish, Rhinobatos halavi (Forsskal, 1775) (Chondrichthyes:Rhinobatidae) in the Mediterranean Sea with a description of a case of albinism in elasmobranchs. Cah. Biol. Mar. 48: 67-75.
occurrence_remarks: A specimen of the Halaves guitarfish, Rhinobatos halavi (Forsskål, 1775) (Chondrichthyes: Rhinobatidae), is recorded off Zarzis, in the Gulf of Gabès, southern Tunisia, confirming the occurrence of this species in the Mediterranean Sea. This species is common in the Red Sea and its presence in the Mediterranean is probably due to migration through the Suez Canal, i.e. Lessepsian migration sensu Golani et al. (2002). R. halavi is the second Lessepsian immigrant elasmobranch species known in the Mediterranean Sea.[...] On the night of 4 September 2004, a 1023 mm total length (TL) female Halaves guitarfish weighing 3005 g was captured 16 miles east to Zarzis (33°29N, 11°25E), in the Gulf of Gabès, southern Tunisia.

occurrence_remarks: The first record of a species of Stomatella from the Mediterranean Sea coast of Turkey is reported. A specimen of Stomatella varia (A. ADAMS, 1850) was collected coincidentally with Patella materials in Göynük, north of Kerner. [] Im November 1999 erhielt das Staatliche Museum fïr Tierkunde Dresden von Herrn RALPH ZENKER (Naturalienkabinett und Heimatmuseum Waldenburg) u. a. Patelliden-Alkoholmaterial von der türkischen Mittelmeerküste von Göynük nördlich Kerner (Karte 1). Auf der Aussenseite einer Patella-Schale sass eine kleine Stomatellide mit einer Gehauselange von 5,3 mm festgehaftet, die von der Autorin als Stomatella varia (A. ADAMS, 1850) determiniert wurde (Abb. 1). Dieser Erstnachweis für das Mittelmeer wird in der Molluskensammlung des Staatlichen Museums fur Tierkunde Dresden unter der Seriennummer 41303 aufbewahrt.

occurrence_remarks: Herzliyya, beach, leg. K.L. Hertz, 8 May 2003 (TAU MO 56425/1). It has the following measurements (height x width) 30.7 x 18.3 mm. The nominal subspecies has a wide distribution in the Indo-Pacific: from East Africa in the west to the Tuamotu Archipelago in the east (Röckel et al., 1995). interestingly exactly 70 years ago Haas (1937 & 1948) reported a find of Conus arenatus on the beach of Atlit, south of the castle. That specimen, a rather old one measuring (height x widt) 38.5 x 22.3 (HUJ 23133/1), belonged to the subspecies living in the Red Sea: Conus arenatus aequipunctatus Dautzenberg, 1937.

occurrence_remarks: A spectacular rise of marine alien biota has been recently documented for the Saronikos Gulf. source: Mienis, H.K. (2003). Trochus niloticus on the beach of Tel Aviv-Yafo: a reminder of the pearl button industry in Israel. SPC Trochus Information Bulletin. 10: 8.
occurrence_remarks: I examined a collection of molluscs that were gathered along the Mediterranean coast of Israel by the late Arieh Hadar. This collection is now part of the National Mollusc Collection of the Tel Aviv University. This review revealed, to my surprise, two specimens of the commercial top shell Trochus niloticus Linnaeus, 1767. Hadar found these specimens on the beach of Tel Aviv-Yafo from 19481968.

occurrence_remarks: Mienis (2003) reported two specimens of this large Topshell from the beach of Tel Aviv-Yafo, leg. A. Hadar, 1948/1968 (TAU 40611 /2). These shells dropped probably in the sea when they were off loaded for the local, already long vanished, pearl button industry.

occurrence_remarks: This study reports the presence of three alien molluscs from Iskenderun Bay (SE Turkey). Amathina tricarinata (Linnaeus, 1767) and Petricola hemprichi Issel, 1869 have prior records from other regions of Mediterranean, but, Cardites akabana (Sturany, 1899) first recorded in this paper. Since all of them are present in the Red Sea or Suez Canal, they can be considered as Lessepsian immigrants. [...] Material examined for Petricola hemprichi Issel, 1869: Eleven specimens were found in holes on the shells of Spondylus spinosus from 7 m depth at Karatas (36o3412 N, 35o3430 E) on 11 August 1999.

occurrence_remarks: Exotic molluscs of the Mediterranean Basin were examined several times, and a list of species from these researches was established (CIESM, 2001). Two species [Siphonaria belcheri Hanley, 1858 and Septifer bilocularis (Linnaeus, 1758)] absent from this list were revealed in this study carried out in Iskenderun Bay, located at southeast Mediterranean coasts of Turkey between the depths of 0-60m and between the years 1999-2001. [...] The second species was Septifer bilocularis (Linnaeus, 1758) [Bivalvia: Mytilidae]. One living specimen from Yumurtalik was attached to Spondylus spinosus Schreibers, 1793 at a depth of 40 m (January 2001). [...] Septifer bilocularis seems to be a Lessepsian migrant since it is present in the Red Sea and the Suez Canal.

source: Mienis, H.K. (2004). New data concerning the presence of Lessepsian and other Indo-Pacific migrants among the molluscs in the Mediterranean Sea with emphasize on the situation in Israel. In B. Oztiirk & A. Salman (Eds.): Proceedings 1st National Malacology Congress, 1-3 September 2004, Izmir. Turkish Journal of Aquatic Life. 2(2): 117-131.
occurrence_remarks: Israel, taken from an off-shore gas produCtion platform, 27 km west off Ashqelon, leg. A. Kotzer, March 2003 (HUJ 9231/5). A previous record of this species from Turkey (Aibayrak & Ceviker, 2001 ), has turned out to have been based on misidentified specimens of the Erythrean species Septifer forskali Dunker, 1855 (Ceviker, 2002). First record from the Mediterranean Sea.

locality: Turkish part of the Mediterranean Sea - Eastern Basin
source: Albayrak, S.; Çaglar, S. (2006). On the presence of Siphonaria belcheri Hanley, 1858 [Gastropoda: Siphonariidae] and Septifer bilocularis (Linnaeus, 1758) [Bivalvia: Mytilidae] in the Iskenderun Bay (SE Turkey). Aquatic Invasions. 1(4): 292-294.
occurrence_remarks: Two alien molluscs (Siphonaria belcheri Hanley, 1858; Septifer bilocularis (Linnaeus, 1758)) were reported from Iskenderun Bay, Turkey by Albayrak and Çeviker (2001). Their descriptive characters were explained in that manuscript but no photographs were given due to the editorial considerations of the journal (Israel Journal of Zoology). The authors of the CIESM Atlas of Exotic Species in the Mediterranean (Zenetos et al. 2003) had not contacted either Albayrak or Çeviker, and chose to consider S. belcheri and S. bilocularis as misidentifications of Siphonaria crenata Blainville, 1827 and Septifer forskali Dunker, 1855 respectively. Albayrak and Çeviker (2001) identified Septifer bilocularis as S. bilocularis var. forskali according to Oliver (1992). Since variety is not a valid taxon, it was reported as S. bilocularis. The explanatory paragraph was deleted by the journal editor. Çeviker (2002) discussed this species and supplied differentiating characters between S. forskali and S. bi

occurrence_remarks: We can here report Chanos chanos (Forskal, 1775) for the first time from the Mediterranean Sea. It is the first Lessepsian immigrant of the family Chanidae, which previously has never been found in the Mediterranean. A specimen of Chanos chanos was caught by a bonito gillnet with 42 mm mesh size and 120 m length. The locality was 2.5 km off the coast of Gazipasa (36°13'N, 32°19'E) at a depth of 20 m on 5 September 2011.

source: Golani, D. (2000). First record of the bluespotted cornetfish from the Mediterranean Sea. Journal of Fish Biology. 56: 1545-1547.
occurrence_remarks: Three specimens of the Indo-Pacific Bluespotted cornetfish Fistularia commersonii are recorded for the first time from the Mediterranean. The presence of this species in the Mediterranean is due to migration from the Red Sea via the Suez Canal. On 10 January 2000, a 516 mm LS specimen, weighing 82.5 g, of Fistularia commersonii Rüppell, 1835, was captured by the trawler F/V Motti, Captain L. Orney, in a haul between Ashdod and Jaffa, Israel, 4.5 km offshore, at a depth of 35 m. [...] Thus bringing the total number of Lessepsian fish migrants to 56. Two additional specimens of F. commersonii were collected on 23 January 2000 on the Mediterranean coast of Israel between Tel-Aviv and Netanya, by the trawler F/V Iris, Captain N. Gluzman, at a depth of c. 15 m.

occurrence_remarks: This note reports the capture of a specimen of honeycomb grouper, Epinephelus merra, in Northwestern Mediterranean Sea. The range of this Indo-Pacific species does not include the Mediterranean Sea, or even the Red Sea or Atlantic Ocean. Its presence would not appear to be due to introduction via the Suez Canal or the Strait of Gibraltar or through ballast waters with shipping. The occurrence of this species is probably due to release from an aquarium.

occurrence_remarks: The Indo-Pacific fish Terapon jarbua is recorded for the first time in the Mediterranean. occurrence_remarks: The Indian scad, Decapterus russelli, is recorded for the first time from the Mediterranean. The presence of this Indo-Pacific species on the Mediterranean coast of Israel is evidently due to migration from the Red Sea via the Suez Canal. [...] On 13 December 2005 six specimens of Decapterus russelli (Rüppell, 1830) of 148-158 mm standard length (SL) were captured by trammel net in the vicinity of Haifa Bay, Israel. [...] With the current reported species Decapterus russelli, the current number of Lessepsian fish migrant species recorded in the Mediterranean has reached 65. [...] The collection of six specimens in the Mediterranean suggests that this species is well established in the Levant.

occurrence_remarks: The Arabian scad Trachurus indicus is recorded for the first time from the Mediterranean Sea (Iskenderun Bay, Turkey). The presence of this Indo-Pacific fish in the Mediterranean Sea is probably because of migration from the Red Sea via the Suez Canal.

occurrence_remarks: La liste des Poissons des côtes libanaises vient d'être enrichie de quatre espéces: Pempheris moluca Cuvier, Lutjanus argentimaculatus (Forsskal), Echelus myrus (Linné), Coelorhynchus coelorhynchus (Risso). Les deux premières d'origine erythréenne sont nouvelles pour la Mediterranée. Elles ont été rencontrées à 20 km au nord de Beyrouth. [...] Un seul exemplaire de [Lutjanus argentimaculatus] de 284 mm a été pêché à la palangre en octobre 1977. Cette espèce est [...] nouvelle pour la Méditerranée.

occurrence_remarks: A specimen of the Japanese threadfin bream Nemipterus japonicus was recorded for the first time from the Mediterranean Sea. The presence of this Indo-Pacific fish in the Mediterranean is evidently due to migration from the Red Sea via the Suez Canal. [...] On 20 February 2005, a 161 mm standard length, Ls, specimen of Nemipterus japonicus (Bloch, 1791) was captured by the trawler F/V Nitzan at a depth of 55 m at the southern edge of Haifa Bay, Israel. The specimen was deposited in the Hebrew University Fish Collection and received the catalogue number HUJ 19280. The finding of N. japonicus in the Mediterranean Sea raises the number of Lessepsian migrant species to at least 62.

[...] This finding represents the first record of the species from Turkey, and represents a significant range extension in the Eastern Mediterranean Sea. [...] Nemipterus randalli appears to have an established population in the Eastern Mediterranean that extends at least from Haifa Bay, Israel, to Cevlik coast of Iskenderun Bay, Turkey.

occurrence_remarks: On October 27, 2003, fishermen of the collective fishery enterprise Put Ilicha, collecting the catch from their trap seine installed in the southern part of Balaklava Bay, found an unusual fish, which was transferred for identification to the Sevastopol Fishery Inspection, and then to the Institute of the Biology of Southern Seas. occurrence_remarks: During scuba diving on rocky substrate at depths of 5-10 m in the Gulf of Antalya, we sighted one Red Sea bannerfish (Heniochus intermedius, Steindachner, 1893). We monitored this specimen for about three months and recorded it by video camera in an underwater cavern. The specimen was caught for identification on 4 September 2002 and morphometric and meristic measurements were taken. Another individual was also seen in the same region during scuba diving.

The specimen (Figure 1) was collected at depths of 20-50 cm, from fouling on the plastic frames of aquaculture fish cage platforms, located at the entrance to the port of Ashdod (Figure 2). This specimen was identi¢ed as Omobranchus punctatus (Valenciennes, 1836) and was deposited in the Hebrew University Fish Collection, receiving the catalogue number HUJ 18977.

occurrence_remarks: Two specimens of a pufferfish, Torquigener flavimaculosus HARDY & RANDALL 1983, were found for the first time on the Mediterranean coast of Israel. These fish were collected on February 17, 1987, on board the stern trawler F/V "NITZAN" from a catch taken in Haifa Bay at a depth of 20 m. One specimen is deposited in the Hebrew University of Jerusalem under the catalogue number HUJ 12062, while the other specimen is deposited in the Senckenberg Museum, Frankfurt a. M., under the catalogue number SMF 21494.

source: Bilecenoglu, M. (2003). Kizildeniz Göçmeni Balon Baligi (Torquigener flavimaculosus Hardy & Randall, 1983), Türkiye kiyilarindan ilk gözlemler. Sualti Dünyasi Dergisi. 74: 38-39.

locality: Greek part of the Aegean Sea
source: Corsini-Foka, M.; Margies, P.; Kondilatos, G.; Economidis, P. S. (2006). Torquigener flavimaculosus Hardy and Randall, 1983 (Pisces: Tetraodontidae) off Rhodes island marine area: a new alien fish in the Hellenic waters. Mediterranean Marine Science. 7(2):73-76.
occurrence_remarks:
The presence of the pufferfish Torquigener flavimaculosus was recorded during the winter 2006-2007 off Rhodes Island (SE Aegean Sea). The species, known from the western Indian Ocean, has established populations from the Levantine basin to Fethiye, Turkey. This finding expands the known range of the species in the Mediterranean to the south-eastern Aegean Sea. [...] Material: Three specimens of Torquigener flavimaculosus Hardy and Randall, 1983 were collected by trawlers at Yalissos, Trianda Bay, NW coast of Rhodes (36o 26 N, 28o 11 E), at depth between 30 and 50m, over a sandy-muddy bottom covered with Posidonia beds.

Change in establishment success from 'casual' to 'established' based on: Zenetos, A.; Meric, E.; Verlaque, M.; Galli, P.; Boudouresque, C.; Giangrande, A.; Cinar, M.; Bilecenoglu, M. (2008). Additions to the annotated list of marine alien biota in the Mediterranean with special emphasis on Foraminifera and Parasites. Mediterranean Marine Science.

occurrence_remarks: The pufferfish Tylerius spinosissimus is recorded for the first time from the Mediterranean Sea. Material examined: A very small specimen, 17.4 mm SL, was collected by the trawl-net (mesh size 10 mm) of the fishing boat Pantelidis, in the bay of Trianda, approximately one mile off the N W coasts of Rhodes Island, on 10 February 2004, at about 90 m depth (Fig. 1, locality A).

occurrence_remarks:
The species was recorded in Israel for the first time in Ashdod (Mienis, unpublished data).

Since Galil (2007), this record has been published in "Mienis, H.K. (2008). New or little known marine molluscs of Red Sea or Indo- Pacific origin from the Mediterranean coast of Israel. Triton. 17: 5-6."

locality: Israeli part of the Mediterranean Sea - Eastern Basin
source: Mienis, H.K. (2008). New or little known marine molluscs of Red Sea or Indo- Pacific origin from the Mediterranean coast of Israel. Triton. 17: 5-6.
occurrence_remarks: Ashdod, beach, in debris at the high water line, leg. H. Feldstein, winter 2001 (TAU MO 58505/1). Only the cuticle was found, of which the upper part is damaged. It shows additional damage caused by birds. The measurements of thus cuticle are (length x width) 66.4 x 28.1 mm. It represents the first record of this Red Sea species from the Mediterranean Sea. No epibionts were found on the cuticle, a sign that most probably it did not float for a long time.

occurrence_remarks: Sepioteuthis lessoniana, identified in this study, is the first Lessepsian squid hitherto recorded from the Levant basin, and thus an important contribution to the Mediterranean teuthofauna. The studied individual was found among a catch brought to the Izmir central fish market from Iskenderun Bay (northeastern Mediterranean), where it was caught by commercial fishing boats on 12 March 2002.

occurrence_remarks: Salman (2002) recorded a specimen caught in the Bay of lskenderun, Turkey. occurrence_remarks: A single specimen of nakedband gaper, Champsodon nudivittis (Ogilby, 1895), indigenous to the Indo West Pacific, was captured on 18 January 2008 from the Iskenderun Bay, Turkey. This is the first record of this species in the Mediterranean Sea. The most likely way of introduction would be via ships ballast waters.

occurrence_remarks: This tropical species [Halgerda sp.] was surprisingly found at the southern tip of the island of Cres near the Baldarin Bay at the end of July 1988. The species was found while collecting other mollusks on a fine gravel bottom from which larger stones had been previously removed. Depth 1 m, water temperature 25°C. To our best knowledge, this is the first record of any Halgerda species in the Mediterranean. The species was taken out of the water and photographed alive in a petri dish filled with seawater. The specimen was tentatively identified as Halgerda willeyi Elliot, 1903. [] The discovery of a nudibranch specimen of the genus Halgerda that has an Indo-Pacific tropical zoogeographical distribution in the northern Adriatic came as a big surprise. The specimen from Cres Island show the visual characteristics of Halgerda willeyi Elliot, 1903, but may well represent a yet unidentified species. A closer and more detailed morphological inspection of the specimen would be necessary for p

locality: Italian part of the Ionian Sea
source: Boero, F., C. Gravili, F. Denitto, M.P. Miglietta & J. Bouillon, 1997. The rediscovery of Codonorchis octaedrus (Hydroidomedusae, Anthomedusae, Pandeidae), with an update of the Mediterranean hydroidomedusan biodiversity. Ital. J. Zool. 64 : 359-365.
occurrence_remarks: Boero & Bouillon (1993) chose the Mediterranean Sea to study the zoogeography of a hydroidomedusan fauna because they considered it the best explored sea of the world for the group. They thus assumed that its basic biodiversity (expressed as number of species) was rather well explored. Since 1993, however, many hydroidomedusan species have been newly recorded from the Mediterranean, besides Codonorchis octaedms: [...] Boero (unpublished) along the Ionian coast of southern Italy (Copanello, Calabria, August, 1996): Clytia hummelincki (Leloup).

occurrence_remarks: Seven species of Scyphomedusae are reported from the Mediterranean coast of Israel. Two of these, Rhopilema nomadica spec. nov. and Phyllorhiza punctata von Lendenfeld, 1884, are Lessepsian migrants new to the Mediterranean. [...] The species appeared off the Israeli Mediterranean coast in the mid-seventies. It has become fairly common in the past decade, appearing in ever larger numbers each year.

occurrence_remarks:

occurrence_remarks: Material was examined from the following Israel localities: Tantura (5.VII.1955, coll. Tel Aviv Institute of Natural Science, 1 ovigerous female of 24 mm), Caesarea (rock pool, VIII. 1952, 1 male of 27 mm), Herzliya (shore, littoral area, 15.VIII. 1951, coll. Tel Aviv Institute of Natural Science, two males of 23 and 28 mm, one ovigerous female of 24 mm), Bat Yam (coll. Tel Aviv Institute of Natural Science, one ovigerous female of 27 mm). [...] In view of the fact that no species of Alpheus belonging to the edwardsii-group are original inhabitants of the Mediterranean (A. audouini and A. crassimanus being Indo-West Pacific forms which evidently have migrated through the Suez Canal) and that the species is too large to be easily overlooked, it seems very probable that, like the last mentioned two species, it is an immigrant from the Red Sea.

occurrence_remarks: Singer (2002) and Mienis (2002b) have reported this well-known Keyhole limpet from the Persian Gulf and Arabian Sea from the coast of Israel. The first specimens dated back to 1998, which were found near Palmahim. Other localities listed were Rishon le Ziyyon, Bat Yam, Yafo and Shefayim. In the meantime it has also been found near Herzliya, leg. K. Hertz, 26 December 2003 (KH/1) and Shiqmona, leg. K. Hertz, 15 September 2001 (KH/1 ). This species seems to be well established along the coast of Israel.

occurrence_remarks: C. pengoi was first discovered in Pärnu Bay and the NE part of the Gulf of Riga on 9 July 1992 (2 ind m-3). In late July and August massive occurrence of that species was observed. Some individuals (2 ind m-3) were found as late as on 5 October 1992. [...] In July-August 1994 massive occurrence of C. pengoi in the NE Gulf of Riga repeated. Bottom trawlings (mesh size 10 mm) were performed in Pärnu Bay and the NE part of the Gulf of Riga on 18 August (stations 1-3) and 23 August (stations 4-6 and a control trawling at station 1) 1994.

source: Galil, B.S.; Lützen, J. (1995). Biological observations on Heterosaccus dollfusi Boschma (Cirripedia: Rhizocephala), a parasite of Charybdis longicollis Leene (Decapoda: Brachyura), a lessepsian migrant to the Mediterranean. Journal of Crustacean biology. 15(4): 659-670.
occurrence_remarks: Since 1993, Heterosaccus dollfusi has been a very common parasite on the crab Charybdis longicollis along the Mediterranean coast of Israel. It accompanied from the Red Sea this Lessepsian migrant crab. [] The host swimming crabs were collected by the R/V Shikmona (Israel Oceanographic and Limnological Research) with a 1.15 m wide beam-trawl, with 5-mm mesh at the cod end. Sampling took place on 29-30 October 1993, 6-7 May, and 11-12 November 1994 at Palmahim, Mediterranean coast of Israel, south of Tel Aviv, at depths of 31-36 m on a sandy bottom.

occurrence_remarks: In 1990 two specimens of an alien species were fished in Italian waters in two localities about 900 km apart: a) Messina; on 4 February 1990, a specimen about 24 cm long was caught by longline. It was neither identified, nor preserved, but it was documented by photocolors, one of which, was published (Biagi, 1990); b) Loano; on 18 october 1990 an artisanal fisherman caught a 32.5 cm-long fish by trammels. M. Torchio deposited it in the collection of the Civica Stazione Idrobiologica of Milan, where it remained uncatalogued.

occurrence_remarks: The occurrence of the solitary ascidian Ciona savignyi Herdman, 1882 in Vostok Bay (Peter the Great Bay, Sea of Japan) was first documented in 2004. Adult specimens occurred in fouling communities of floating docks in Gaidamak Bay and on different anthropogenic substrates. The introduction of this ascidian into Vostok Bay is attributable to fishing ships which regularly frequent ports of Japan and to favorable environmental conditions (temperature and salinity of seawater).
